column1: The Epley maneuver is a series of head movements to relieve symptoms of benign positional vertigo.
Benign positional vertigo is also called benign paroxysmal positional vertigo (BPPV).
BPPV is caused by a problem in the inner ear.
BPPV occurs when small pieces of bone-like calcium (canaliths) break free and float inside small canals in your inner ear.
Your provider will use this procedure to treat BPPV.

During the procedure, you may experience: - Intense vertigo symptoms - Nausea - Vomiting (less common) In a few people, the canaliths may move into another canal in the inner ear and continue to cause vertigo.
For severe vertigo, your provider may give you medicines to reduce nausea or anxiety before starting the procedure.
Most of the time, treatment will cure BPPV.
Your doctor may prescribe medicines that can help relieve spinning sensations.
